name: Eurasian Oystercatcher
description: Unmistakable due to its contrasting coloration and piercing call. It is almost entirely black, with a white chest and belly. It has a bright orange beak and pink legs. A white wing stripe is visible in flight.
spread_note: Coasts and inland northern Europe, eastward to the Caspian Sea region, parts of eastern and southern Asia, western and northeastern Africa, New Zealand—partially migratory
proportions: Body length 20–24 cm, tail length 10–11.5 cm, wing length 23.7–27 cm, weight 0.4–0.8 kg
attractions: Its name hints at its habitat: shores of seas or large inland lakes, where it feeds mainly on crustaceans and mussels, skillfully opening them with its strong beak.
breeding: Oystercatchers lived in the waterfowl pavilion in the 1970s. Modern breeding began in 1998 with a pair from Arnhem Zoo, with the first successful breeding in 2001.
